In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Following the global financial crisis of 2008–2009, financial stability has become the 
focus of reforms across the Group of Twenty (G20) and beyond. Even in countries that are less 
globally integrated, efforts to strengthen macrofinancial stability have become more pressing. In 
a  rapidly  globalizing  world,  national  and  international  financial  stability  are  interlinked—
supporting a call for strengthening reforms to develop a more effective national framework, 
including institution building and capacity development to strengthen financial stability. 
 
2.  In response to the crisis, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) held a series of policy 
dialogues known as the ADB Regional Forum on the Impact of the Global Economic and 
Financial Crisis, as a platform for developing member countries’ senior policy makers and the 
private sector to discuss the implications and measures taken to mitigate the impacts of the 
crisis and, equally as important, to take stock of the longer term implications for the region. 1 
Through these dialogues, developing member countries have sought support from ADB to 
develop a policy framework that would enable its member countries to rebuild their institutional 
capacities to effect necessary reform initiatives, and target interventions that would support 
sustained growth and financial stability. Smaller economies, including Bhutan and the Maldives, 
sought ADB assistance to develop the foundations for monitoring, examining, and addressing 
risks to financial stability. Such support is expected to translate into a more effective early 
warning system, including timely recognition of financial vulnerabilities across financial systems. 
In particular, with improved capacity to monitor external shocks, supervisory and regulatory 
authorities may adopt timely and appropriate measures to ensure that these shocks do not 
escalate into crises.  
 
3.  In  this  context,  ADB  commissioned  two  studies  on  developing  a  macrofinancial 
monitoring and surveillance system for Bhutan and the Maldives in 2010.2 A mission visited 
Bhutan and the Maldives in 2011 to present the findings of the studies to the two governments. 
This was followed by visits in June 2012 to both countries with more detailed discussions with 
senior officials from the Ministry of Finance and the central banks i.e., the Royal Monetary 
Authority of Bhutan (RMA) and the Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA). The governments and 
the  mission  reached  an  understanding  on  the  objectives,  scope,  financing  plan,  and 
implementation details of the technical assistance (TA). The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
      
4.  Under their financial stability objective, central banks have been mandated to support 
improved macroeconomic and financial management by developing monitoring and surveillance 
frameworks  based  on  leading  indicators  to  better  understand  shocks  and  transmission 
mechanisms—given the state of the fundamentals—and how to shore up vulnerabilities to 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for South Asia Forum on the Impact of the Global Economic and 
Financial Crisis. Manila (RETA 6508). ADB held a series of policy dialogues across countries in Asia 
and the Pacific in March 2009 and January 2010 in Manila. 
2  In 2010, ADB commissioned two studies on Bhutan and the Maldives: (i) A. Mansur. 2011. Bhutan: 
Impact of the Global Financial Crisis, Improving Monitoring Mechanisms and Maintaining/Strengthening 
Capability for Policy Response. Dhaka: Policy Research Institute of Bangladesh; and (ii)  A. Mansur. 
2011.  Maldives:  Global  Financial  Crisis  and  Vulnerability,  Improving  Monitoring  Mechanism  and 
Strengthening Capability for Policy Response. Dhaka: Policy Research Institute of Bangladesh. A 
follow-up  mission  to  Bhutan  was held  on  11–12 July  and  the Maldives on  12 October 2011,  to 
disseminate the findings of the studies, leading to the scope and design of this TA.

2   
mitigate against any adverse impact on the economy. Proactive policy actions involve the 
formulation of appropriate macroprudential regulations and the ability to monitor and enforce 
effective financial supervision and the impact on the real economy. It also involves active 
liquidity management to ensure that interest rate setting is supportive of price stability and 
overall macrofinancial management considerations. Policy instruments should be developed, 
including lender of last resort, discount window, reserve requirements, liquidity rations, and 
appropriate interest rate policy, which serve as intermediate targets to achieve the desirable 
policy objectives and avoid systemic risks. As such, a central bank’s monetary policy, prudential 
and supervisory roles are complementary and can promote conditions to steer the economy 
back to a stable and steady-state potential growth path over the medium term.  
 
5.  In South Asia, particularly in the smaller open economies of Bhutan and the Maldives 
with nascent financial markets, banks dominate the financial system. Like many developing 
countries that share prevalent (although not universal) features, Bhutan and the Maldives have 
greater dependence on foreign funding, including development assistance, weaker institutional 
frameworks and market infrastructure, important capacity constraints, greater involvement of the 
state in the financial system, and greater use of international currencies for domestic financial 
transactions. In addition, Bhutan follows a currency peg with the Indian rupee while the Maldives 
recently exited the currency peg with the US dollar and now follows a managed float. Against 
this backdrop, maintaining economic resilience over the medium term is a major challenge, as 
both these economies begin to access foreign capital markets and become more integrated with 
the regional and global economy.  
 
6.  Financial stability measures for Bhutan and the Maldives are relatively weak as a result 
of data limitations, capacity constraints, and the lack of appropriate policy instruments to carry 
out their respective central bank’s regulatory and supervisory functions. High frequency data are 
often unavailable; the instruments are either inexistent or too blunt, and efforts should be 
concentrated on developing data along with more refined policy instruments. An example is 
interest rate setting, whereby in the absence of a deep and sufficiently liquid government 
securities  market,  reforms  should  be  introduced  to  develop  an  interest  rate  instrument—
beginning at the short end of the yield curve—that effectively prices demand and supply of 
overnight, money market, and eventually short-term loanable funds in the market. Monetary 
authorities are sometimes too passive in their interventions, such as in liquidity management 
practices, whereby some forward indicators can be developed to support more active liquidity 
management. 
 
7.  The proposed TA will assist Bhutan and the Maldives in developing a macroprudential 
framework and a liquidity management plan and strategy, which are important measures for 
developing a regionally coordinated surveillance mechanism to support financial stability across 
South  Asia  and  building  on  regional  reform  initiatives  with  other  international  financial 
institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, to strengthen banking and 
financial systems in South Asia. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact of the TA will be stronger financial stability for sustaining growth in Bhutan 
and the Maldives. The outcome of the TA will lead to improved capacity of the RMA and MMA 
for regulation and supervision of the financial sector.

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The TA will deliver three major outputs:  
(i)  Developed macroprudential policies, tools, and monitoring framework.3 The 
first component will support the RMA and MMA in developing macroprudential 
policies and framework for monitoring and examining financial soundness. This 
entails (a) a review and conduct of gap analysis of the RMA and MMA’s current 
practices  for  systemic  stability  regulation,  including  assessment  of  staffing 
resources needed for performing financial stability monitoring functions in the 
central bank; (b) preliminary study, design, identification, and collection of better 
information  and  data  (macroeconomic  and  financial  soundness  indicators)  to 
support systemic risk identification and modeling; (c) design of an early warning 
system or techniques to identify and measure systemic risk, including stress 
testing,  following  international  best  practices;  (d)  design  of  appropriate 
macroprudential instruments; and (e) preparation of guidelines and production of 
pilot financial stability reports. 
 
 (ii)   Improved liquidity management plan and strategy. The second component 
will assist the RMA and MMA in developing a liquidity management plan and 
strategy. This entails (a) review and conduct of a needs assessment of present 
liquidity  measurement  and  management  in  Bhutan  and  the  Maldives, 
(b) development of an effective liquidity management plan, which covers liquidity 
risk management policy and liquidity management strategy in the context of 
Bhutan and the Maldives; and (c) preparation of a road map to implement the 
liquidity management plan and strategy in a phased manner.  
 
(iii)   Enhanced capacity and training of central bank staff in performing financial 
stability  functions.  The  third  component  will  provide  resources  to  support 
capacity  building  of  key  central  bank  staff  in  performing  the  functions  of 
macroprudential regulation and liquidity management. This entails (a) capacity 
and training needs assessment; (b) development of detailed training manuals on 
the preparation of financial stability reports; (c) design of a training manual for the 
new liquidity management strategy; and (d) conduct of in-house training program 
for key central bank staff on macroprudential monitoring, stress testing, and 
liquidity management. 
 
10.  It is assumed that the governments of Bhutan and the Maldives will continue to give high 
priority to support regulation and supervision practices and make available relevant data and 
staff resources for the implementation of the outlined outputs and corresponding activities. The 
team of international consultants hired under this TA will work in both countries—with national 
consultants—to build a common approach to TA deliverables and ensure cost-effectiveness. A 
major risk is the lack of commitment from the central bank to introduce and apply financial 
stability  mechanisms,  i.e.,  macroprudential  policies  and  monitoring,  and  an  active  liquidity 
management strategy to their regulatory and supervisory functions. In addition, failure to recruit 
and/or retain the necessary senior level staff to work with international experts on various 
initiatives, as designed under the TA, is another risk.   
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s

3  The output of this TA will support ADB’s proposed intervention in Bhutan on Strengthening Economic Management 
Program for improved macroprudential and financial sector management to meet tranche policy conditions.  The 
proposed TA also complements ADB’s upcoming intervention in Bhutan on capital market development.

4   
 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund4 and administered by ADB. The governments 
of Bhutan and the Maldives will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, use 
of office facilities for consultants and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will be the executing agency, and the RMA and MMA will be the implementing 
agencies. The implementing agencies will provide furnished office space for the consultants, 
access to a conference room, and local communication facilities for the consultants. Both the 
RMA and MMA will provide counterpart staff as necessary. 
 
13.  To  achieve  the  planned  outcome,  three  international  consultants  and  two  national 
consultants will be recruited under one consulting firm to provide a total of 28 person-months of 
consulting  services.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3. 
Consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). For training and workshops, the advance payment facility could be used.   
 
14.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  intermittently  over  24  months,  from  February  2013  to 
February 2015. The consulting firm will submit to the RMA, MMA, and ADB the following: 
(i) inception reports 2 weeks after commencement of consulting services; (ii) interim progress at 
appropriate stages during TA implementation; (iii) draft final reports before the conclusion of the 
contract; and (iv) final reports after receiving comments from the RMA, MMA, and ADB. Major 
project activities will be regularly monitored and reported on by the RMA, MMA, and ADB 
administration missions. The inception report and finalization of the draft final reports will be 
discussed at tripartite meetings involving the RMA, MMA, the consultants, and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund for Supporting Financial 
Stability in Bhutan and the Maldives, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Implementation of the technical assistance (TA) will require a total of 16 person-months 
of international consultants and 12 person-months of national consultants.  
2.  The terms of reference of the consultants, who will be responsible for the delivery and 
quality of the outputs outlined under the TA, are as follows: 
 
(i)  Developed macroprudential policies, tools, and monitoring framework.1 The 
first component will support the Royal Monetary Authority of Bhutan (RMA) and 
the Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA) in developing macroprudential policies 
and framework for monitoring and examining financial soundness. This entails 
(a) a review and conduct of gap analysis of the central bank’s current practices 
for systemic stability regulation; (b) preliminary study, design, identification, and 
collection  of  better  information  and  data  (macroeconomic  and  financial 
soundness  indicators)  to  support  systemic  risk  identification  and  modeling; 
(c) design  of  early  warning  systems  or  techniques  to  identify  and  measure 
systemic  risk,  including  stress  testing,  following  international  best  practices; 
(d) design of appropriate macroprudential instruments; and (e) preparation of 
guidelines and production of pilot financial stability reports. 
 
 (ii)   Improved liquidity management plan and strategy. The second component 
will assist the RMA and MMA in developing a liquidity management plan and 
strategy. This entails (a) review and conduct of a needs assessment of the 
present liquidity measurement and management in Bhutan and the Maldives; 
(b) development of an effective liquidity management plan, which covers liquidity 
risk management policy and liquidity management strategy in Bhutan and the 
Maldives;  and  (c)  preparation  of  a  road  map  to  implement  the  liquidity 
management plan and strategy in a phased manner.  
 
(iii)   Enhanced capacity building and training of central bank staff. The third 
component will provide resources to support capacity building of key central bank 
staff  performing  the  functions  of  macroprudential  regulation  and  liquidity 
management.  This  entails  (a)  capacity  and  training  needs  assessment; 
(b) development  of  detailed  training  manuals  on  the  preparation  of  financial 
stability reports; (c) design of training manual for the new liquidity management 
strategy; and (d) conduct of an in-house training program for key central bank 
staff on macroprudential monitoring, stress testing, and liquidity management. 
 
3.  Monetary  management  expert  (team  leader,  international,  10  person-months, 
intermittent). The expert and team leader should have a postgraduate degree in economics and 
proven experience and expertise in macroprudential regulations, having advised and worked 
with central banks. The expert should have the prerequisite senior level skills and experience 
and knowledge of financial regulatory practices and economic analysis. The team leader will 
take overall responsibility for the quality and timely delivery of the outputs under the TA. The 
team leader will submit an inception report to the RMA, MMA, and ADB within 2 weeks of the 
start of work and a draft final report 2 weeks before the end of the engagement. The team 
leader will undertake the following tasks:  
                                                 
1  The output of this TA will support ADB’s proposed intervention in Bhutan on Strengthening Economic Management 
Program for improved macroprudential and financial sector management to meet tranche policy conditions.

(i)  preparing a detailed work plan to achieve the outputs of the TA, including the 
required deliverables, tasks, and timing of each task. 
(ii)  coordinating the work of the international and national consultants for the quality 
and timely completion of all TA outputs; 
(iii)  taking the lead in designing macroprudential policies and instruments in Bhutan 
and the Maldives in collaboration with the liquidity management expert engaged 
under  the  TA,  which  includes  drafting  operating  guidelines  and  rules  on 
(a) countercyclical capital buffer for banks, (b) loan-to-value and loan-to-income 
restriction, (c) sectoral capital requirements, (d) time-varying capital provisioning 
and  margin  requirements,  (e)  debt-to-equity  ratio  for  project  financing, 
(f) restrictions on distribution of profit, and (g) bank disclosure requirements; 
(iv)  designing the framework and taking the lead in publishing pilot financial stability 
reports for Bhutan and the Maldives; 
(v)  preparing detailed training manuals on (ii) and (iii); 
(vi)  finalizing the liquidity management strategy plan in consultation with the liquidity 
management expert engaged under the TA;  
(vii)  designing  and  conducting  training  workshops  (along  with  other  international 
experts or other resource persons that may engaged under the TA) for key 
central bank staff on macroprudential regulations, stress testing and monitoring, 
and liquidity management within budget;  
(viii)  preparing terms of reference of resource person(s) (if any) and managing all in-
house training and capacity building specified under the TA outputs within budget; 
and 
(ix)  conducting the final dissemination workshop on the TA outputs. 
 
4.  Liquidity  management  expert  (international,  4  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
liquidity management expert should have a postgraduate degree in economics and relevant 
experience in bank liquidity and financial risk management functions in a central bank. Working 
closely with the team leader, the expert will take responsibility for the delivery of output (ii) under 
the TA. Specifically, the expert will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)     reviewing and assessing the liquidity management mechanisms and practices of 
the MMA and RMA; 
(ii)    designing an appropriate liquidity management plan and strategy for Bhutan and 
the  Maldives  by  ensuring  consistency  with  the  macroprudential  regulation, 
working in close collaboration with the lead consultant; 
(iii)  preparing a road map for the implementation of a liquidity management plan for 
the RMA and MMA; 
(iv)  designing a training manual for the new liquidity management strategy;  
(v)   conducting a training workshop on liquidity management with relevant central 
bank staff, i.e., training of trainers; and 
(vi)  assisting the team leader in designing the framework for the financial stability 
report and drafting the relevant portions of the first financial stability reports for 
Bhutan and the Maldives.

(ii)   preparing models for financial sector stress testing and scenario analysis for

6.  National  consultants  (6 person-months, intermittent, one each for Bhutan and the 
Maldives). Under the supervision of the team leader, the national consultants should have 
strong  academic  background  in  economics  and  extensive  work  experience  in  research, 
economics and financial data collection and analysis. Work experience with central banks in the 
area of prudential regulations and financial surveillance would be an advantage. The national 
consultants will assist the team of international consultants and will be responsible for the 
following tasks, including but not limited to: 
(i)  assisting the international consultants with research, data collection, and analysis; 
(ii)  organizing and supervising the field surveys with relevant agencies, as applicable; 
(iii)  assisting in the preparation of periodic reports and training manuals;  
(iv)  coordinating the field assignments of international consultants with central bank 
and other relevant agencies, as required; 
(v)  assisting in the administration of training and workshops; and 
(vi)  assisting international consultants in the timely delivery of all outputs required 
under the TA.
